Table 2 Samples Specific Surface Area (m2/g) Acidity (μmol/g) Pore volume (cm3/g) Pore diameter (nm) CeMo/Ti 52.298 66.85 0.297 29.591 0.44P-CeMo/Ti 56.818 111.38 0.237 12.235 0.88P-CeMo/Ti 42.638 100.02 0.192 1.948 1.32P-CeMo/Ti 23.88 46.04 0.129 1.951 The poisoning effects of phosphorus on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 DeNO x catalysts: NH3-SCR activity and the formation of N2O Yanchen You a Huazhen Chang a ⁎ Tong Zhu b Tao Zhang b Xiang Li b Junhua Li b a School of Environment and Natural Resources, Renming University of China, Beijing 100872, China School of Environment and Natural Resources Renming University of China Beijing 100872 China b School of Environment, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China School of Environment Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this paper, the poisoning effects of phosphorus on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts were investigated for their role in selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3 (NH3-SCR) applications. A series of P-poisoned CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. To investigate the deactivation mechanism of NH3-SCR, the samples were characterized by BET, NH3-TPD, XPS, in situ DRIFTS studies and NH3 catalytic oxidation. The activity tests showed that the DeNOx activity declined significantly after phosphorus loading, and a large quantity of N2O formed over the poisoned catalysts. It was found that the active metal sites at the surface were covered by phosphate (mainly cerous phosphate). The chemical deactivation effects of phosphorus on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 mainly resulted from decreases in the number of active sites and in the adsorption capacity for NOx species. As the loading of phosphorus reached 1.32%, physical deactivation effects, e.g., severe changes in thermal stability and surface structure, also accounted for the decline in activity. The formation of substantial amounts of N2O after phosphorus loading, despite heavily poisoned Ce-sites, might be attributed to Mo-sites being mildly poisoned across the CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. Thus, after phosphorus loading, the NH3-SCR occurred mainly on Mo-sites. Lastly, the increase in N2 selectivity at high temperatures with the increasing phosphorus loadings was clarified by a kinetics study. Keywords NH3-SCR Phosphorus poisoning CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 Deactivation N2 selectivity 1 Introduction In recent years, the poisoning effects of the phosphorus compounds in flue gas on NH3 selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) catalysts have gained increasing attention, especially in the flue gas obtained from the co-combustion of fossil fuels with mixtures that have high amounts of phosphorus compounds, such as municipal waste and sewage sludge [1,2]. The deactivation effects of phosphorus on V-based commercial SCR catalysts have been studied more comprehensively. Beck et al. [2,3] collected commercial catalysts from several power plants and found that all of them had a large quantity of phosphorus on the catalyst’s surface. After analysis, the decrease in the specific surface area and the pore condensation were proposed to be responsible for the decline of activity. Castellino et al. [4] thought that the decrease of active V-sites mainly accounted for the deactivation, and it was found that the catalysts exposed to flue gas with phosphoric acid were much more deactivated than the catalysts that were poisoned by being impregnated in a phosphoric acid solution in lab. The phosphorus deactivation mechanisms of other NH3-SCR catalysts, such as Fe/BEA, Cu/BEA, MnO2/TiO2 catalysts, have also been studied preliminarily. Shwan et al. [5] found that metaphosphates could form on Fe/BEA catalysts after a long enough exposure to a H3PO4 gas flow, and they concluded that the metaphosphates were replacing the hydroxyl groups on the active iron species, which deactivated the NH3-SCR. Andonova et al. [6] studied the deactivation effects of phosphorus on Cu/BEA and proposed that deactivation occurred because of a decrease in active Cu species due to the formation of phosphate. Yang et al. [7] investigated the deactivation mechanism of phosphorus on a MnO2/TiO2 low temperature NH3-SCR catalyst, and the characterization results suggested that decreased redox behavior and the inhibition of the adsorption of NOx species mainly accounted for phosphorus’s poisoning effects. All of the above results showed that the acidity of the catalysts increased after phosphorus poisoning. However, the role of this increased surface acidity and the reason why NH3-SCR activity declined significantly despite the improvement in surface acidity were not clear. In addition, another important assessment parameter, the N2 selectivity of NH3-SCR after phosphorus poisoning, had not yet been studied. The Ce-based catalysts have become popular for their outstanding oxygen storage capacity. In particular, Ce-based NH3-SCR catalysts (such as CeO2/TiO2, CeO2-MoO3, CeO2-MnO2), have excellent DeNOx activity and much better resistance to H2O and SO2 than commercial V-based catalysts [8–14]. Among them, CeO2/TiO2 is especially promising [15,16]. Doping MoO3 into CeO2/TiO2 enhanced the NH3-SCR activity and the resistance to H2O and SO2 [17,18]. As an emerging NH3-SCR catalyst, CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 has excellent NH3-SCR activity and better resistance to H2O and SO2 than commercial V-based catalysts [17,18]. In addition, the outstanding N2 selectivity of Ce-based catalysts could help reduce the emission of the greenhouse gas N2O, which has 310 times the global warming potential (GWP) of CO2 and has become the most important ozone-depletion gas in recent years [19]. Moreover, the lower toxicity of CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 makes it more practical. However, the effects of phosphorus in flue gas should be clarified before using it for NH3-SCR commercially. Chang et al. [20] found that the CeO2-MoO3 NH3-SCR catalyst was deactivated by increased phosphorus loading and that the doping of MoO3 into CeO2 enhanced the resistance to phosphorus poisoning. The research suggested that CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 SCR catalysts would be poisoned by flue gas containing phosphorus compounds. However, the further study of P-poisoned CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 is necessary to clarify the deactivation mechanism and guide industrial application. This work prepared P-poisoned CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts with different phosphorus loadings and observed the decline in SCR activity. Unexpectedly, a large quantity of N2O formed over P-poisoned CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts. Based on the NH3-SCR and catalyst characterization results, the deactivation mechanism and abnormal N2 selectivity of P-poisoned CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 were elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and P-poisoning The catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method as described previously [17,18]. The catalysts CeO2/TiO2, MoO3/TiO2, and CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 are here shortened to Ce/Ti, Mo/Ti, and CeMo/Ti, respectively. Ce/Ti consists of 10wt% CeO2 and 90wt% TiO2. Mo/Ti consists of 5wt% MoO3 and 95wt% TiO2. CeMo/Ti consists of 10wt% CeO2, 5wt% MoO3 and 85wt% TiO2. The P-poisoned catalysts were prepared by impregnating a corresponding amount of NH4H2PO4 into samples in aqueous solution, then drying at 110°C for 12h and calcining at 500°C for 4h [20]. The poisoned samples were denoted with their mass fraction of phosphorus as a prefix, such as 0.44P-CeMo/Ti or 1.32P/Ti. 2.2 Catalytic performance The steady-state NH3−SCR was performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor. The reaction conditions were as follows: 500ppm NH3, 500ppm NO, 3% O2, N2 balanced with a gross gas flow rate of 200mlmin−1, 0.15g of catalyst (40–60mesh), GHSV=7.1×104 h−1 (STP). The same system and inlet gas concentration were also used to estimate the oxidation of NH3 and temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD). The concentrations of NO, N2O, and NH3 were measured by an FT-IR gas analyzer (Gasmet Dx-4000). The NO conversion was calculated from the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO as follows: N O c o n v e r s i o n = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % The DeNOx activity of the SCR was characterized by NO conversion. The N2 selectivity was calculated from: N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = { 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t } × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterization The BET specific surface area was measured by N2 physisorption at 77K with a Quantachrome Nova specific surface area analyzer. Powder XRD pattern measurement was performed on an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, D/max-2200/PC, Japan) between 10 and 80° at a step of 7° min−1 operating at 30kV and 30mA with Cu Kα (λ=0.15405nm) radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained with an ESCALab220i-XL electron spectrometer from VG Scientific. A total gas flow rate of 200mlmin−1 and a catalyst of 0.15g were maintained during the NH3-TPD experiment. The experimental procedures were as follows: (1) degasification of catalyst in a N2 flow at 400°C for 1h; (2) cooling to 100°C and then adsorption in an NH3 +N2 flow for 1h; (3) removal of physically adsorbed NH3 in a N2 flow for 1h; (4) temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 at a constant heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a N2 flow until 600°C was reached. The NH3 adsorption quantity (Qads) was calculated from: Q ads = A des × Q c 22.4 R T × m cat where Ades stands for the area of the desorption peak (ppm °C), Qc stands for the flow rate (Lmin−1) at standard conditions, RT stands for the heating rate (°Cmin−1), mcat stands for the mass of the employed catalyst (g). In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was recorded by a Nicolet Nexus 6700 spectrometer. The sample underwent degasification in a flow of N2 at 400°C for 1h, followed by cooling to the test temperature, where it was maintained for 10min before background scanning. 3 Results 3.1 Effects of phosphorus on NH3-SCR performance The NH3-SCR activity of CeMo/Ti with different phosphorus loadings was evaluated as a function of temperature. The results are presented in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 1(a), the CeMo/Ti catalyst exhibited nearly 100% NO conversion in a wide temperature range from 300 to 400°C. However, with increased phosphorus loadings, NO conversion exhibited a significant decrease. At 400°C, only 57% NO conversion was obtained over 1.32P-CeMo/Ti. The significant decline in SCR activity revealed clearly that the CeMo/Ti catalyst was heavily deactivated by phosphorus. In addition, Fig. 1(b) shows that much more N2O formed over the P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalysts than the fresh CeMo/Ti catalyst, especially 0.44P-CeMo/Ti. Even though 89% NO conversion was obtained over 0.44P-CeMo/Ti at 400°C, outlet N2O concentration was 272ppm, leading to an N2 selectivity of only 42.1%. The above results demonstrated that increased phosphorus loading also lowered the N2 selectivity, generating much more N2O. Surprisingly, from 300 to 400°C (i.e., the practical working temperature range), the N2 selectivity increased as the phosphorus loading increased from 0.44% to 1.32% (Table 1). Furthermore, the 1.32P/Ti had barely any SCR activity or N2O formation over it, which indicated that the P-sites and Ti-sites were not active sites and that the SCR activity and N2O formation were mainly obtained over the active Ce-sites and Mo-sites. Water is always present in the exhausts, the effects of H2O on both SCR activity and N2O formation over CeMo/Ti and P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalysts are showed in Fig. 2 . After the addition of H2O, the SCR activity over all catalysts at higher temperature range (from 250 to 400°C) was inhibited, whereas the activity at 150°C was slightly promoted. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the introduction of H2O also inhibited the formation of N2O severely. Moreover, the simultaneous decrease of NO conversion and N2O formation leads to the disorder of N2 selectivity. 3.2 Catalyst characterization correlation with the decline of activity 3.2.1 XRD patterns The XRD patterns of CeMo/Ti with different phosphorus loadings are shown in Fig. 3 . The unlabeled peaks were ascribed to the rutile or anatase phases of TiO2. A weak peak, corresponding to cubic CeO2 crystals, appeared over fresh CeMo/Ti. However, the crystalline MoO3 phase was absent because MoO3 was highly dispersed on the surface of the TiO2. Above a 0.44% phosphorus loading, the patterns hardly changed, because only a certain amount of phosphorus could become highly dispersed on the surface of the CeMo/Ti. However, as the phosphorus loading reached 1.32%, the peaks of cubic CeO2 almost disappeared and a weak peak of CePO4 emerged. It suggested that the phosphate precursor (NH4H2PO4) turns into a phosphate radical, forming cerous phosphate with the trivalent cerium after calcination. 3.2.2 BET specific surface area and NH3-TPD There is a general agreement that the NH3-SCR starts with the adsorption of NH3 [21,22]. The specific surface area and the adsorption capacity of specific sites greatly influence the adsorption of NH3. The BET specific surface area and NH3-TPD results are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 2 . Interestingly, 0.44P-CeMo/Ti exhibited the highest specific surface area. This may result from the formation of a nanostructure after phosphorus loading [23]. However, with further increases of the phosphorus loading, the specific surface area decreased significantly. Additionally, the pore volume and pore diameter decreased sharply with increased phosphorus loadings. It suggested that the P-poisoned CeMo/Ti sintered easily, which means that the thermal stability of CeMo/Ti was negatively affected by phosphorus loading. The NH3-TPD results were also interesting. Although the SCR activity declined with increased loadings of phosphorus, the strongest acidity (calculated from NH3-TPD results) was obtained from 0.44P-CeMo/Ti. The acidity of 0.88P-CeMo/Ti was also stronger than that of fresh CeMo/Ti, and the 1.32P-CeMo/Ti had the lowest acidity. The differences in overall NH3 adsorption capacity, i.e., acidity, resulted from the changes to the specific surface area and the NH3 adsorption capacity provided by P-sites. H3PO4 is a mediate strong acid, and thus the oxo compounds of phosphorus on CeMo/Ti have a large number of Brønsted acid sites, i.e., the hydroxy groups [4]. The NH3 adsorption DRIFT spectrum of 1.32P/Ti (Fig. 6(a)) also supports this analysis. The P site’s ability to adsorb NH3 had a positive effect on the overall NH3 adsorption capacity, but the specific surface area also had a large influence on it. These two main factors lead to the differences in the overall NH3 adsorption capacity. 3.2.3 XPS results XPS was carried out to illustrate the change of surface components after phosphorus poisoning. Fig. 5 (a) shows the XPS results Ce 3d, the bands labelled as u stand for 3d3/2 spin–orbit states and those labelled as v represented 3d5/2 states. The bands labeled u′ and v′ were ascribed to the electronic state corresponding to Ce3+, and those labeled u and v, u″ and v″, u‴ and v‴ were assigned the electronic state corresponding to Ce4+. After 0.44% phosphorus loading, the bands corresponding to Ce4+ decreased obviously, especially the u″ and v″, u‴ and v‴ bands. But the u′ and v′ bands corresponding to Ce3+ increased significantly. It suggested that massive surface Ce4+ turned into Ce3+ after phosphorus loading. In consideration of XRD patterns, the formation of CePO4 could be concluded. After 1.32% phosphorus loading, the bands corresponding to Ce4+ and Ce3+ both decreased, it might result from the decrease of specific surface area. The XPS results of Mo 3d were showed in Fig. 5(b). Two bands corresponding to Mo6+ were observed. With the increasing loading of phosphorus, the two bands decreased gradually. 0.44P-CeMo/Ti owed bigger surface area but fewer surface Mo6+, which suggested the masking of active Mo-sites by phosphorus loading. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the peak of the bands corresponding to P 2p shifted to higher binding energy with the increasing of phosphorus loading. The electronegativity of cerium and molybdenum is 1.12 and 2.16, respectively. The chemical shift might from the stronger electron withdrawing ability of molybdenum. It implied the more formation of molybdic or molybdenic phosphate after 1.32% phosphorus loading. In other words, the phosphorus tended to bond with Ce-sites rather than Mo-sites over CeMo/Ti. 3.2.4 In situ DRIFTS studies To get a better understanding of the differences in NH3 (NO+O2) adsorption over P-poisoned CeMo/Ti, the NH3 (NO+O2) adsorption over 1.32P/Ti was also studied under the same conditions. Fig. 6(a) shows the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption over 1.32P/Ti, CeMo/Ti, 0.44P-CeMo/Ti and 1.32P-CeMo/Ti at 100°C. The bands at 1611 and 1208cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations, respectively, of NH3 coordinated to Lewis acid sites [22,24], and the bands at 1430 and 1673cm−1 can be assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations, respectively, of surface NH4 + species [25,26]. The bands at 3399, 3258 and 3169cm−1 can be assigned to the NH stretching vibration modes [27]. The weak shoulder at 1550cm−1 is ascribed to −NH2 species, which are important intermediates [22,24]. Several bands in the range of 1900–1700cm−1 were also observed on CeMo/Ti catalysts, and they could be assigned to the NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites [17]. The wave trough appearing at 3564cm−1 results from the disappearance of surface hydroxy [24]. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the high intensity of band at 1430cm−1 and the wave trough appearing at 3564cm−1 for 1.32P/Ti indicated that a large quantity of NH3 had absorbed onto Brønsted acid sites (surface hydroxy). In addition, similar results were also observed for 1.32P-CeMo/Ti, which has a relatively low intensity compared to 1.32P/Ti. The disappearance of surface hydroxy resulted from the formation of NH4 + species. It suggests that additional NH3 can adsorb onto the Brønsted acid sites provided by the P-sites of P-poisoned CeMo/Ti. Comparing the bands (1611, 1208 and 1258cm−1) mainly related to the NH3 coordinated to Lewis acid sites, it is clear that the intensity decreased as the phosphorus loading increased. In addition, the band representing −NH2 species that appeared in fresh CeMo/Ti was not observed in 0.44P-CeMo/Ti or 1.32P-CeMo/Ti. It also suggested that the NH3 coordinated with either P-sites or Ti-sites could not be activated to form −NH2 species directly, for the oxidation state of phosphorus and titanium are stable. Fig. 6(b) shows the DRIFT spectra of NO+O2 adsorption onto 1.32P/Ti, CeMo/Ti, 0.44P-CeMo/Ti and 1.32P-CeMo/Ti at 100°C. The bands at 1611, 1512cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric vibration of bridging nitrate and monodentate nitrate, and the bands at 1575 and 1247cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of bidentate nitrate, respectively [28–30]. The band at 1723cm−1 can be assigned to the adsorption of trans-(NO)2 [31,32]. The DRIFT spectrum of 1.32P-CeMo/Ti was changed substantially by the phosphorus loading. In general, the intensity of most bands decreased with increasing loadings of phosphorus. It is clear that the adsorption of NOx species was also obstructed by the phosphorus loading. The reaction of pre-adsorbed NH3 with NO+O2 and pre-adsorbed NO+O2 with NH3 was also examined at 200°C. As shown in Fig. 7 , the pre-adsorbed NH3 (coordinated NH3 and NH4 +) reacted completely in 5min over fresh CeMoTi catalyst and the bands corresponding to oxo compounds of nitrogen subsequently appeared. While the pre-adsorbed NH4 + on a phosphorus-containing catalyst reacted slowly and could even be observed after 20min. This suggested that the NH4 + adsorbed on P-sites is more difficult to react with NO+O2 than NH4 + on Ce-sites and Mo-sites. As for the reaction of pre-adsorbed NO+O2 with NH3, the DRIFT spectra (not shown) implied that it was not active at 200°C. The bands corresponding to NO+O2 adsorption hardly changed when NH3 was introduced, and the changes in the DRIFT spectra resulted from the adsorption of NH3. 3.3 Catalyst characterization correlation with N2O formation 3.3.1 NH3-SCR of Ce/Ti and Mo/Ti To study the different roles of Ce-sites and Mo-sites over CeMo/Ti in the NH3-SCR process, NH3-SCR experiments were performed with Ce/Ti and Mo/Ti. As shown in Fig. 8 , Ce/Ti had much better NH3-SCR activity than Mo/Ti, and the 5% MoO3 loading promoted the Ce/Ti SCR activity greatly. Nevertheless, the formation of N2O in these catalysts showed that Ce/Ti had the best N2 selectivity, with almost no N2O formed. In contrast, the N2 selectivity of Mo/Ti was quite low. At 400°C, Mo/Ti obtained only 38.4% N2 selectivity. In addition, the N2 selectivity of Mo/Ti is similar to the N2 selectivity of 1.32P-CeMo/Ti, which implied that the N2O formation mainly resulted from the Mo-sites rather than the Ce-sites. 3.3.2 NH3 selective catalytic oxidation The oxidation of NH3 was thought to be an important source of N2O formation during NH3-SCR [33]. For this reason, NH3 selective catalytic oxidation (NH3-SCO) on CeMo/Ti with different phosphorus loadings was evaluated as a function of temperature. The NH3 conversion results are presented in Fig. 9 . As the phosphorus loading increased, the NH3 conversion and the N2O conversion concentration both declined significantly. The N2 selectivity of the NH3 catalytic oxidations was relatively high, i.e., mostly above 80%. The first step of the NH3 selective catalytic oxidation is the adsorption of NH3 onto the catalyst [25]. Both 0.44P-CeMo/Ti and 0.88P-CeMo/Ti had stronger acidity than fresh CeMo/Ti, whereas the NH3 conversion was much lower than that of fresh CeMo/Ti. In addition, the decline in NH3 conversion revealed that the redox activity of CeMo/Ti was also hindered by phosphorus loadings. 4 Discussion 4.1 The decline of SCR activity The formation of N2 and N2O via the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism and the Eley–Rideal (E-R) mechanism, respectively, over fresh and P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalysts can be approximately described as the following reactions [21,22,34,35]: L-H mechanism: (1) N O ( g ) → N O ( a d ) (2) N O ( ad ) + ≡ M n + + ≡ O 2 − → N O 2 − + ≡ M ( n − 1 ) + (3) N O 2 − + N H 4 + → N H 4 N O 2 → N 2 + 2 H 2 O (4) 2 N O ( a d ) + 3 2 O 2 + ≡ O 2 − → ≡ M n + 2 N O 3 − (5) N O 3 − + N H 4 + → N H 4 N O 2 → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O (6) ≡ M ( n − 1 ) + + 1 4 O 2 → ≡ M n + + 1 2 ≡ O 2 − E-R mechanism: (7) N H 3 ( g ) → N H 3 ( a d ) (8) N H 4 + → N H 3 ( a d ) (9) N H 3 ( a d ) + ≡ M n + → − N H 2 + ≡ M ( n − 1 ) + + H + (10) − N H 2 + N O ( g ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O (11) − N H 2 + ≡ M n + → − N H + ≡ M ( n − 1 ) + + H + (12) − N H + N O ( g ) → − N H N O ( a d ) (13) − N H N O ( a d ) + ≡ M n + + ≡ O 2 − → N 2 O + ≡ M ( n − 1 ) + + ≡ O H − (14) ≡ M ( n − 1 ) + + 1 4 O 2 → ≡ M n + + 1 2 ≡ O 2 − In this study, phosphorus compounds were loaded onto the stable surface of CeMo/Ti where Ce-sites and Mo-sites were dispersed homogeneously. With 1.32% phosphorus loading, the CeMo/Ti catalyst sintered and the specific surface area decreased sharply. Then, a CePO4 phase appeared while the CeO2 phase mostly disappeared. Because of the increased loading of phosphorus and the sintering of the catalyst, the highly dispersed CePO4 crystallized and became detectable. In other words, the active surface Ce-sites became coated with phosphate radicals. The XPS results of Ce 3d and Mo 3d also revealed the formation of CePO4 and the significant decrease of surface Ce4+ and Mo6+. Additionally, the increase of Brønsted acid sites (mainly provided by phosphorus compounds) and decrease of Lewis acid sites and NOx adsorption capacity (Fig. 6) also implied that phosphorus compounds had covered the catalyst surface and thus masked the active Ce-sites and Mo-sites. Based on the above results, it was concluded that the decrease in active Ce-sites and Mo-sites greatly affected the decline in NH3-SCR activity. The NH3-TPD results (Fig. 4) showed that 0.44P-CeMo/Ti and 0.88P-CeMo/Ti have a higher NH3 adsorption capacity, i.e., stronger acidity, than fresh CeMo/Ti. However, the DRIFT spectra of the NH3 adsorption (Fig. 6(a)) revealed that the P-poisoned CeMo/Ti adsorbed more NH3 on Brønsted acid sites (mainly provided by P-sites) and less NH3 on Lewis acid sites (mainly provided by Ce-sites and Mo-sites). The 1.32P/Ti had almost no activity, so the P-sites on CeMo/Ti can be regarded as adsorption sites rather than active sites. Thus, the NH4 + adsorbed on P-sites can react directly with nitrate or nitrite adsorbed on nearby Ce-sites and Mo-sites via the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism (Reactions (3) and (5)), but it cannot be activated to form NH2 species by the P-sites. Alternatively, the NH4 + on P-sites can only transfer to active metal sites (Reaction (8)) for further reaction. However, the DRIFT spectra of NO+O2 adsorption showed that the extent of NOx adsorption decreased significantly after phosphorus loading, and thus the reaction via the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism was heavily hindered. Meanwhile, the transfer from P-sites to active Ce-sites and Mo-sites was difficult, according to the DRIFT spectra of Fig. 7. Overall, the NH3-SCR activity declined in spite of the enhanced acidity. In addition, the decrease in the number of Lewis acid sites also contributes to the decline of NH3-SCR activity. Reaction (10) states that N2 production rates rely on the intermediate amide (NH2). Reaction (9) shows that the decreased number of Lewis acid sites and active metal sites were unfavorable for amide formation, thus diminishing the N2 production rates and deactivating NH3-SCR. The above reasons that account for the deactivation effects are mainly chemical factors, but as the phosphorus loading reached 1.32% and higher, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter decreased sharply. This suggested that CeMo/Ti catalysts sintered easily after a certain amount of phosphorus loading, which hurt its thermal stability and surface structure. Thus, physical deactivation effects might play a more important role after loading large quantities of phosphorus. 4.2 The formation of N2O The formation of N2O mainly results from two pathways: NH3 non-selective oxidation (NSNO, Reaction (15)) and NH3 non-selective catalytic reduction (NSCR, Reaction (16)) [33]. During NH3-SCR process, there is a competition for NH3 between NSNO and NSCR. (15) 2NH 3 + 2 O 2 → N 2 O + 3 H 2 O (16) 4NH 3 + 4 NO + 3 O 2 → 4 N 2 O + 6 H 2 O The comparison of outlet N2O concentration during NH3-SCR and NH3-SCO is shown in Fig. 10 . In the practical working temperature window (300–400°C), outlet N2O concentrations all increased with temperature during both NH3-SCR and NH3-SCO. The amount of N2O formed from either NH3-SCR or NH3-SCO, catalyzed by fresh CeMo/Ti catalyst, was comparable, suggesting that during the NH3-SCR process, the NSCO contributed substantially to the formation of N2O. After phosphorus loading, massive amounts of N2O formed during NH3-SCR over the P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalysts, especially the 0.44P-CeMo/Ti catalyst. Meanwhile, the N2O concentration from NH3-SCO declined significantly. NH3-SCR and NH3-SCO, catalyzed by P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalysts, produced N2O in different orders of magnitude. Considering that there was competition for NH3 during the SCR process, the contribution of NSCO to N2O formation was very small. Comparing these results demonstrates that the formation of N2O during the SCR process mainly originated from NSCR, rather than NSNO. NSCR forms N2O from two paths. Reactions (4) and (5) show that adsorbed NO3 −, which originates from the over-oxidation of adsorbed NO, reacts with adsorbed NH3 to form adsorbed NH4NO3 and then adsorbed NH4NO3, which decomposes to N2O and H2O. Reactions (11) and (12) show that the −NH that originated from the cleavage of the NH bond of NH2 reacts with gaseous NO to ultimately form N2O and H2O. There was almost no N2O formation over Ce/Ti, but a large quantity of N2O formed over Mo/Ti (Fig. 8), which indicated that the N2O formation was mainly catalyzed by Mo-sites rather than Ce-sites. A drop in N2 selectivity was also observed after the MoO3 doping of a V2O5/TiO2 catalyst [36,37]. Wang et al. [38] found that further increasing the MoOx content in CeMo catalysts results in the formation of large amounts of N2O. Thus, Mo-sites are responsible for the formation of N2O over CeMo/Ti. Additionally, the XPS results of P 2p of 0.44P-CeMo/Ti and 1.32P-CeMo/Ti suggested that phosphorus tended to bond with Ce-sites rather than Mo-sites. As a result, a conclusion that the phosphorus tends to poison Ce-sites rather than Mo-sites in a CeMo/Ti catalyst was proposed to explain the massive formation of N2O after phosphorus loading (Fig. 11 ). Because the Ce-sites and Mo-sites compete for the removal of NO, only a little N2O formed over CeMo/Ti. However, as the phosphorus loading increased, the Ce-sites were heavily inhibited, while the Mo-sites were only slightly poisoned. As a result, Mo-sites started to dominate the SCR progress, generating massive amounts of N2O. Table 1 presents the N2 selectivity of different catalysts from 300 to 400°C. It is obvious that the N2 selectivity of P-poisoned CeMo/Ti was much lower than that of CeMo/Ti. However, as the phosphorus loading increased from 0.44% to 1.32%, the N2 selectivity gradually increased in the practical working temperature window (300–400°C). Chang et al. [20] also reported that 3.9P-Ce-Mo-O exhibited better much better N2 selectivity than 1.3P-Ce-Mo-O. This phenomenon can be explained by a kinetics study. The comparison of the reaction of pre-adsorbed NH3 with NO+O2 and pre-adsorbed NO+O2 with NH3 (Section 3.2.4) suggested that NO was mainly reduced via the Eley–Rideal mechanism. Additionally, it is generally accepted that the Eley–Rideal mechanism is obviously promoted by increases in reaction temperature, which allows it to predominate over SCR at higher temperatures [21,35]. Therefore, it was reasonable to conclude that N2 and N2O mainly formed via the Eley–Rideal mechanism within the practical working temperature window. To simplify the kinetic study, the catalytic effects of heavily poisoned Ce-sites were ignored. Accordingly, Mo/Ti models a P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalyst where the Ce-sites were totally deactivated but the Mo-sites were still fresh. The formation of N2 and N2O via the Eley–Rideal mechanism is described in Reactions (7)–(14). In a steady-state NH3-SCR: (17) d [ N 2 ] d t = k 1 [ − N H 2 ] [ N O ( g ) ] (18) d [ − N H ] d t = k 2 [ − N H 2 ] [ ≡ M o 6 + ] − k 3 [ − N H ] [ N O ( g ) ] (19) d [ N 2 O ] d t = d [ − N H N O ] d t = k 3 [ − N H ] [ N O ( g ) ] where k1-k3 is the kinetic constant of Reactions (10)–(12), respectively, and [NH2] and [NH] are the concentration of the intermediate products NH2 and NH, respectively. The ratio of N2 production to N2O production can be described as the ratio of the N2 formation rate to the N2O formation rate: (20) d [ N 2 ] d [ N 2 O ] = d [ N ] 2 d t / d [ N 2 O ] d t = k 1 [ − N H 2 ] k 3 [ − N H ] At a steady-state NH3-SCR, the concentration of −NH is a constant. Thus, (21) d [ − N H ] d t = k 2 [ − N H 2 ] [ ≡ M o 6 + ] − k 3 [ − N H ] [ N O ( g ) ] = 0 (22) [ − N H 2 ] [ − N H ] = k 3 [ N O ( g ) ] k 2 [ ≡ M o 6 + ] according to Eq. (20), thus, (23) d [ N 2 ] d [ N 2 O ] = k 1 [ N O ( g ) ] k 2 [ ≡ M o 6 + ] Eq. (23) shows that the ratio of N2 production to N2O production was proportional to the concentration of NO(g) in the reactor and inversely proportional to the amount of active Mo-sites of catalysts. The XPS results of Mo 3d revealed that the amounts of active Mo-sites gradually decreased with the increasing loadings of phosphorus, and the concentration of NO(g) in the reactor was higher due to the decreased deNOx activity. Accordingly, the ratio of N2 production to N2O production increased, and thus the N2 selectivity (300–400°C) gradually increased. Mo/Ti, which had better NO conversion and more active Mo-sites than P-poisoned CeMo/Ti, had a lower N2 selectivity than that of P-poisoned CeMo/Ti. 5 Conclusions The NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity of CeMo/Ti declined significantly after phosphorus loading. The surface active metal sites were covered by phosphate (mainly cerous phosphate), and the masking of active sites is one of the most important chemical factors for deactivation. In addition, the significant decrease in the NOx adsorption capacity explained why the NH3-SCR activity declined in spite of the improvement in surface acidity. Lastly, as the phosphorus loading reached 1.32%, physical deactivation effects, such as the adverse impact on thermal stability and surface suture, contributed significantly to the decline in activity. The formation of substantial amounts of N2O after phosphorus loading mainly originated from non-selective catalytic reduction rather than non-selective NH3 oxidation. The massive N2O formation demonstrated that Ce-sites were heavily poisoned while Mo-sites were mildly poisoned. Lastly, this kinetics study on SCR over P-poisoned CeMo/Ti catalysts will be helpful for understanding differences in N2 selectivity. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, the poisoning effects of phosphorus on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts were investigated for their role in selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3 (NH3-SCR) applications. A series of P-poisoned CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. To investigate the deactivation mechanism of NH3-SCR, the samples were characterized by BET, NH3-TPD, XPS, in situ DRIFTS studies and NH3 catalytic oxidation. The activity tests showed that the DeNOx activity declined significantly after phosphorus loading, and a large quantity of N2O formed over the poisoned catalysts. It was found that the active metal sites at the surface were covered by phosphate (mainly cerous phosphate). The chemical deactivation effects of phosphorus on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 mainly resulted from decreases in the number of active sites and in the adsorption capacity for NOx species. As the loading of phosphorus reached 1.32%, physical deactivation effects, e.g., severe changes in thermal stability and surface structure, also accounted for the decline in activity. The formation of substantial amounts of N2O after phosphorus loading, despite heavily poisoned Ce-sites, might be attributed to Mo-sites being mildly poisoned across the CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. Thus, after phosphorus loading, the NH3-SCR occurred mainly on Mo-sites. Lastly, the increase in N2 selectivity at high temperatures with the increasing phosphorus loadings was clarified by a kinetics study.
coredata.dc:title: The poisoning effects of phosphorus on CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 DeNO x catalysts: NH3-SCR activity and the formation of N2O
